options: Advise your colleague that their behaviour is inappropriate
Decide to work late to finish any outstanding tasks
Explain to your colleague that you are very busy and need their support
Inform a senior colleague that you are not receiving the support required
Leave your colleague to sleep, and ignore the pager so that you can catch up on outstanding tasks
questions:
You are working a night shift in the surgical ward. One of your colleagues informs you that they are going for their 30-minute break. One hour later they have not returned and you are extremely busy with a long list of jobs. You go to the doctor's mess to find the colleague asleep.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
This question is focussed on good communication and teamwork skills when working with a colleague who is underperforming. This is highlighted in the GMC Good Medical Practice's - Communication, Partnership and Teamwork domain, and the Maintaining Trust domain. This GMC guidance specifically advises: 'When you are on duty you must be readily accessible to patients and colleagues seeking information, advice or support'.

Explaining to your colleague that you are very busy and need their support is the most appropriate action since it is clear, direct, polite and professional.

Advising your colleague that their behaviour is inappropriate is somewhat appropriate. Although they are entitled to a break, by overrunning their allocated time they have placed an unfair burden on you. However, this is not as good an option since it does not explain to your colleague your concerns on how busy the ward is and furthermore does not explicitly advise that help is required.

Inform a senior colleague that you are not receiving the support required. Again this is a somewhat appropriate action as would allow a senior to help find adequate cover. It would also allow a senior colleague to sensitively explore any possible complex issues behind your colleague's poor performance. However, it is not as good an option as above, as it is generally best to address issues directly in the first instance.

Deciding to work late to finish any outstanding tasks is inappropriate. Despite the good intentions, this is an unfair burden and has possibly patient safety implications since mistakes can occur when overtired.

Leaving your colleague to sleep, and ignoring the pager so that you can catch up on outstanding tasks is entirely inappropriate. Patient safety is clearly at risk due to this option.

Deciding to work late to finish any outstanding tasks is inappropriate. Despite the good intentions, this is an unfair burden and has possibly patient safety implications since mistakes can occur when overtired.

Leaving your colleague to sleep, and ignoring the pager so that you can catch up on outstanding tasks is entirely inappropriate. Patient safety is clearly at risk due to this option.
title: GMC: Leadership and management for all doctors - Working with colleagues
body:
As with all aspects of medicine, the fundamental principle remains the same; make the patient your first concern. The purpose of this guidance is to allow the effective functioning of the clinical team to allow patient care to be done safely and smoothly, to the highest standards.

Leadership

The recommendations on leadership emphasise the importance of working within a multidisciplinary team. They specifically mention that other team members in leadership positions must be respected. This respect for non-medical staff in leadership roles is important.

For example, respecting the advice and leadership of an infection control nurse with regard to hand hygiene is important in making patients are protected from iatrogenic pathogen spread.

Respect for colleagues

If a colleague feels like they are not respected and not valued they may not feel able to speak up if they have concerns which may be relevant to patient safety. This is particularly important for junior and non-medical staff, and so it especially important to respect and value their skills and contribution to the team.

Additionally there is both a legal and moral responsibility to ensure that your colleagues have a safe and fair workplace. All doctors are responsible for facilitating this not only to avoid unpleasant behaviour themselves, but also by challenging others who act in a bullying or discriminatory manner. This is important both to comply with laws and policies on equality and diversity, but also to ensure patient safety as bullying and harassment will impair team cohesion and communication.


Communication within and between teams

The key message from this part of the guidance is that it is important that it is clear who is responsible for communicating what information both within members of the team, to other teams, and also to patients and carers. Mistakes are often made when team members assume that someone else will have passed on the relevant information and no one ends up doing it. Therefore whenever there is any doubt about whose job it is to pass on certain information, it is obligatory to check.

For example, if you expect that the nursing staff would have told you about any allergies the patient has, before prescribing it would be important to confirm with them that they have handed over all the relevant information.

Also it is important that teams cooperate more generally, including by having handovers. Proactive steps must be taken to clarify responsibilities and improve communication.

Responsibility and accountability

The most important duty of a doctor is to the dignity, safety and care of their patients. Again, it is important for doctors to ensure that it is clear exactly which staff members have which responsibilities, to ensure that these do not 'fall between the cracks' and get missed.

It is also important that you make these responsibilities clear to any staff in a team that you are leading.

When mistakes happen, it's often the result of system problems. For example it could be under-staffing putting decision making under higher strain, causing more mistakes. This happened in the Bawa-Garba case, the tragic death of a child from unrecognised sepsis on a day where a single doctor was trying to cover multiple wards.

Consequently, it is also the responsibility of doctors to engage in setting up and maintaining systems to make sure that risks are appropriately assessed and managed. Doctors are just as accountable for advice they give as a member of a decision making body, as they are for any other medical advice they offer.
links:
GMC00
Leadership and management for all doctors - Working with colleagues

options: Discuss the reasons for not wanting surgery with the patient
Ask consultant to discuss the surgery with the patient further
Speak to the patient about scarce NHS resources and the effects of cancellations
Send patient for surgery
Cancel the patients surgery
questions:
You are a junior doctor on a respiratory ward. One of your patients, who has been diagnosed with an operable lung tumour, requests to speak to you regarding their scheduled surgery. When you speak to them they say that they are worried and do not want to have the surgery. They are scheduled in for surgery this later this morning.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Having surgery is a traumatic experience for most people, and it is only natural that nerves and doubts exist prior to it. It is the job of the medical team to inform the patient of the risks and benefits of surgery and help them to make an informed decision, without applying any pressure to select one option or another. Therefore, the most appropriate response to this scenario would be to take the time to discuss the reasons behind the patient not wanting surgery (1). This will allow the patient time and the opportunity to discuss their thoughts and concerns regarding the surgery, and the ability to ask you questions which may help them to make a final decision regarding the surgery.

The next most appropriate response would be to ask the consultant to discuss the surgery with the patient further (2). This option would be an appropriate response, however, it does not address the patients worries and concerns in the same way that option 1 does.

Cancelling the surgery (5) is an over-reaction to the situation, as you have not explored the reasons for the patient changing their mind. A simple discussion could put the patient's mind at rest and reassure them that surgery is the best option. Cancelling the surgery without doing this could potentially waste NHS resources. Speaking to the patient about scarce NHS resources and the effects of cancellations (3), however, is an inappropriate response to this question. This would be applying soft pressure to the patient, meaning they might feel obliged to have the surgery when they don't want it.

Sending the patient for surgery (4) is unacceptable. The patient has expressed their wish to not have surgery, and by sending them for surgery anyway you are breaking their autonomy. Furthermore, performing surgery on an unconsenting patient could be classed as assault, placing your surgical team in a difficult situation.

options: Ignore it, this is in the patients best interest
Immediately interrupt explaining that this is not allowed on NHS time
Tell your clinical supervisor what you observed
Speak to the consultant after clinic about your concerns.
Tell the medical director what you observed
questions:
You are a ST doctor sitting in on a clinic when your consultant tries to persuade a patient to see him privately in order to reduce the time he will have to wait for an operation.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The most appropriate response, as with situational judgement questions in general, is to speak to the relevant person first, regardless of their seniority. (B)

This may be a matter that needs to be discussed with other senior staff members, therefore you clinical supervisor is a good resource for advice and to take the issue further (C). The medical director could also help with this but you are unlikely to have a working relationship with them (E). Interrupting the consultant in clinic which would be unprofessional in front of a patient (B). The worst option is to take no action at all in this situation (A).
question:
You are a ST doctor sitting in on a clinic when your consultant tries to persuade a patient to see him privately in order to reduce the time he will have to wait for an operation.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)

options: Refuse to speak to him until he has calmed down
Call security
Tell him that the department is busy and everyone has to wait their turn
Offer to speak to him in a quiet place
Apologise to him for the wait
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in a busy Emergency Department. The waiting times for patients can be very long, however, you are getting through your workload as quickly as possible. You are taking a 5-minute break to go to the toilet when a patient stops you, expressing his 'annoyance' and 'frustration' at having been made to wait for so long. What do you do?

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
Difficult situations can usually be de-escalated by listening and good communication. In situations with a distressed or angry patient, the best way to deal with it is to calm the situation down. You can apologise for the wait, find out if there is anything you can do and try to resolve the situation. This should all be done in a quiet room rather than the middle of the waiting room. Hopefully, in the first instance this will be enough to resolve the situation. Remember, apologising is not an admission of guilt and can open the channels of communication.

Telling him to 'wait his turn' may sound patronising and is likely to aggravate the situation further.

There is no suggestion that the patient is being aggressive hence telling the patient to 'calm down' is not helpful.

Finally, calling security at this stage is disproportionate to the issue. Verbal de-escalation and compromise will resolve this far easier than involving security.

title: GMC: Good Medical Practice - Maintaining trust
body:
Maintaining trust is one of the four domains in Good Medical Practice.

Key points include
  • Show respect for patients
  • Treat patients and colleagues fairly and without discrimination
  • Act with honesty and integrity

Please see the link for more details.
concept: Difficult situations can usually be de-escalated by listening and good communication
links:
GMC00
Good Medical Practice - Trust and Professionalism

options: Continue to work despite the pain.
Take some codeine and naproxen from the drug cupboard at work.
Book an appointment to see your GP, taking sick leave from work.
Ask a colleague to prescribe stronger analgesia for you.
Book into the Emergency Department during your lunch break.
questions:
You are a junior doctor working on a cardiology firm. Whilst playing rugby at the weekend you develop a lower back injury. You pain is not adequately controlled by paracetamol and ibuprofen. You are having difficulty driving to work and walking long distances due to pain. You are on the rota to work long shifts all week.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes: In this scenario your personal health should take priority over your work commitments. The correct course of action is to book an appointment with your GP (whether in person or via the telephone). Although misuse of the Emergency Department system should be avoided, it is preferable to taking medicines from work or putting your colleague in the difficult position of prescribing for you.
question:
You are a junior doctor working on a cardiology firm. Whilst playing rugby at the weekend you develop a lower back injury. You pain is not adequately controlled by paracetamol and ibuprofen. You are having difficulty driving to work and walking long distances due to pain. You are on the rota to work long shifts all week.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
question_notes: In this scenario your personal health should take priority over your work commitments. The correct course of action is to book an appointment with your GP (whether in person or via the telephone). Although misuse of the Emergency Department system should be avoided, it is preferable to taking medicines from work or putting your colleague in the difficult position of prescribing for you.

options: Tell the secretary all you know from when you first clerked the patient
Inform the secretary that it is against patient confidentiality to disclose any information
Tell her you are not entirely sure and it would be better if she spoke to the registrar
Find the patient and gain their permission to talk to the daughter
Pretend you urgently have to be elsewhere and that you can't help her
questions:
Earlier today you clerked a 63-year-old lady who subsequently was found to have generalised peritonitis secondary to a ruptured bowel. The registrar has just finished consenting the patient for a Hartmann's procedure. On leaving the emergency department, a respiratory secretary approaches you. She claims she is the patient's daughter and would like to know what has happened.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
D is the best option here since you are addressing the situation and attempting to sort it out by taking the initiative to find the patient to see whether it would be ok for you to pass on any information to her daughter.

Although B is correct, you are just stating a fact and not really addressing the situation hence B is ranked lower than A.

Again with C, you are not addressing the daughters query. Here you are just shifting responsibility on to someone else, who may be busy and not have the time currently to speak with the daughter, in a situation which can easily be sorted by yourself hence is ranked lower.

E and A are the worst options. E is clearly very unhelpful. Option A breaks patient confidentiality since you haven't gained consent from the patient first and is therefore ranked lowest.
question:
Earlier today you clerked a 63-year-old lady who subsequently was found to have generalised peritonitis secondary to a ruptured bowel. The registrar has just finished consenting the patient for a Hartmann's procedure. On leaving the emergency department, a respiratory secretary approaches you. She claims she is the patient's daughter and would like to know what has happened.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)

E and A are the worst options. E is clearly very unhelpful. Option A breaks patient confidentiality since you haven't gained consent from the patient first and is therefore ranked lowest.

options: Reflect in your e-portfolio
Stop and offer assistance
Continue driving as people are already on scene
Call 999 immediately
Direct traffic away from the scene
questions:
You are a junior doctor working on an intensive care unit. It is your weekend off, and you are going to a family party. Whilst driving down a country lane, you see that a road traffic collision has occurred. There is a car in the middle of the road and two other drivers have already stopped to help. What do you do?

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
As a doctor, you have a moral obligation to help those in trouble. If the emergency services have not yet arrived, you are likely to be the most appropriately trained to help in this situation, therefore you should stop and offer what assistance you can.

If not already done so, you must call 999 so that the patient can be taken to hospital if necessary.

Although as a doctor your skills are best placed helping those involved, to direct traffic would be more immediately helpful than to reflect in your e-portfolio or to continue driving. Continuing to drive is the worst answer.
question:
You are a junior doctor working on an intensive care unit. It is your weekend off, and you are going to a family party. title: GMC: Good Medical Practice - Maintaining trust
body:
Maintaining trust is one of the four domains in Good Medical Practice.

Key points include
  • Show respect for patients
  • Treat patients and colleagues fairly and without discrimination
  • Act with honesty and integrity

Please see the link for more details.
concept: As a doctor you have a moral obligation to help those in trouble, and this may sometimes happen outside of work
links:
GMC00
Good Medical Practice - Trust and Professionalism

options: Inform the Emergency Department matron
Contact the NMC
Discuss this with her
Fill in a Datix
Reflect in your eportfolio
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in the Emergency Department. While doing some paperwork at the nurses' station you look up to notice a nurse taking medicines from the controlled drugs cabinet. You suspect she is stealing them for herself as she puts them in her pocket rather than on the trolley she is preparing. What do you do?

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
The best option, as always, is to first discuss this with her. There may be a perfectly valid explanation for what she is doing. If you are still not satisfied, you should inform the Emergency Department matron, who will investigate and may need to act on your concerns. If you have a concern, you do not need to wait for proof, you will be able to justify raising a concern if you do so honestly, on the basis of reasonable belief and through appropriate channels, even if you are mistaken. Either you or the matron will need to complete a Datix of the incident if wrongdoing is found, hence it is the next best option.

Contacting the NMC without further evidence is a poor option. However, the may at least address the issue one way or the other.

Reflecting on the incident in your e-portfolio does nothing to resolve the issue at hand
question:
You are a junior doctor working in the Emergency Department. While doing some paperwork at the nurses' station you look up to notice a nurse taking medicines from the controlled drugs cabinet. You suspect she is stealing them for herself as she puts them in her pocket rather than on the trolley she is preparing. What do you do?

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)

Contacting the NMC without further evidence is a poor option. However, the may at least address the issue one way or the other.

Reflecting on the incident in your e-portfolio does nothing to resolve the issue at hand
title: General Medical Council: duties of a doctor
body:
Make the care of your patient your first concern

Protect and promote the health of patients and the public
  • Provide a good standard of practice and care
  • Keep your professional knowledge and skills up to date
  • Recognise and work within the limits of your competence
  • Work with colleagues in the ways that best serve patients' interests

Treat patients as individuals and respect their dignity
  • Treat patients politely and considerately
  • Respect patients' right to confidentiality

Work in partnership with patients
  • Listen to patients and respond to their concerns and preferences
  • Give patients the information they want or need in a way they can understand
  • Respect patients' right to reach decisions with you about their treatment and care
  • Support patients in caring for themselves to improve and maintain their health

Be honest and open and act with integrity
  • Act without delay if you have good reason to believe that you or a colleague may be putting patients at risk
  • Never discriminate unfairly against patients or colleagues
  • Never abuse your patients' trust in you or the public's trust in the profession.
concept: If you have concerns about the behaviour or integrity of a colleague, it is best to discuss this with them in person in the first instance

options: Accept her invitation as you are leaving the practice soon
Discuss the matter with the practice manager and have her banned from attending the practice again
Do not speak to her any more and block her from contacting you
Invite her in for an appointment to ensure she is on contraception and had recent testing for Chlamydia prior to going on the holiday with her
Politely decline and tell the practice manager about her behaviour
questions:
You are a junior doctor nearing the end of a rotation at a GP surgery. A woman has been coming to see you frequently to manage her type 2 diabetes and she is very grateful for the way you have treated her. She invites you to join her for a private holiday after your rotation has finished as she would like to get to know you better. You are aware it will just be the two of you sharing a single room.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
The correct order, from most to least appropriate, is ECBAD.

We must maintain professional boundaries between ourselves and patients. In this case, a current patient appears to be attempting to begin a sexual relationship with you whilst still your patient. The scenario suggests they require frequent input from healthcare professionals for their diabetes and as such is likely to be a vulnerable patient. Explaining you cannot go politely and flagging her behaviour to the practice manager is the most appropriate way to deal with the scenario. The practice manager can subsequently speak to the patient and apologise and explain that it is inappropriate for doctors to have non-professional relationships with their patients.

Not speaking to the patient again and blocking her from contacting you will prevent an inappropriate relationship. However, without explaining to the patient why it is inappropriate, it risks her behaving in the same way with future doctors once you have left the practice. Additionally, it could affect how she views medical professionals and result in her diabetic care being affected.

Discussing the matter with the practice manager and having her banned is a poor option. A patient with type 2 diabetes is clearly at risk of medical complications and banning her from accessing the practice may result in harm being caused.

Accepting her invitation is a poor option. The patient is a vulnerable person and going on holiday with her whilst she is still your patient is unacceptable. Even if you are leaving the practice soon, you still have a duty of care to her and going on holiday with her will affect how she views medical professionals.

Inviting her in for a discussion around contraception and testing for sexually transmitted infection (STI) is the worst option. You are using your position as her doctor to influence her into taking contraception and performing tests for an STI for your gain.
question:
You are a junior doctor nearing the end of a rotation at a GP surgery. A woman has been coming to see you frequently to manage her type 2 diabetes and she is very grateful for the way you have treated her. She invites you to join her for a private holiday after your rotation has finished as she would like to get to know you better. You are aware it will just be the two of you sharing a single room.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
question_notes:
The correct order, from most to least appropriate, is ECBAD.

We must maintain professional boundaries between ourselves and patients. In this case, a current patient appears to be attempting to begin a sexual relationship with you whilst still your patient. The scenario suggests they require frequent input from healthcare professionals for their diabetes and as such is likely to be a vulnerable patient. Explaining you cannot go politely and flagging her behaviour to the practice manager is the most appropriate way to deal with the scenario. The practice manager can subsequently speak to the patient and apologise and explain that it is inappropriate for doctors to have non-professional relationships with their patients.

Not speaking to the patient again and blocking her from contacting you will prevent an inappropriate relationship. However, without explaining to the patient why it is inappropriate, it risks her behaving in the same way with future doctors once you have left the practice. Additionally, it could affect how she views medical professionals and result in her diabetic care being affected.

Discussing the matter with the practice manager and having her banned is a poor option. A patient with type 2 diabetes is clearly at risk of medical complications and banning her from accessing the practice may result in harm being caused.

Accepting her invitation is a poor option. The patient is a vulnerable person and going on holiday with her whilst she is still your patient is unacceptable. Even if you are leaving the practice soon, you still have a duty of care to her and going on holiday with her will affect how she views medical professionals.

Inviting her in for a discussion around contraception and testing for sexually transmitted infection (STI) is the worst option. You are using your position as her doctor to influence her into taking contraception and performing tests for an STI for your gain.
title: GMC: Maintaining a professional boundary between you and your patient
body:
The GMC is very explicit that doctors must not use their position to pursue a sexual or inappropriate relationship with a patient. This is to ensure that trust between doctors and patients is maintained.

Current patients
  • You must not engage in a sexual or emotionally inappropriate relationship with a patient.
  • You must not terminate a professional relationship with a patient in order to pursue a personal relationship.

Former patients
  • Here the GMC has slightly less hard and fast rules. For former patients, the timing of the professional relationship and the vulnerability of the patient are very important.

Timing
  • If you have treated a patient for a long time then this is more likely to be inappropriate.
  • If your professional relationship with the patient has only just ended then this is more likely to be inappropriate.

Vulnerability
  • If the patient was vulnerable when you were their doctor, such as young adults and those with mental illness, then it is not appropriate to pursue a relationship with them regardless of the elapsed time.
  • If the person is still vulnerable then it is of course not appropriate to pursue a personal relationship with them.

Examples

You are a GP trainee and you see a patient for one consultation about a minor sporting injury. You then meet this person in the local pub and hit it off. This is likely appropriate as you have not used a position of power or responsibility to further the relationship.

You are a GP trainee and have been seeing a patient regularly during your attachment. They have confided in you that their partner is abusive. You have helped them to find support groups and they leave their partner. It would be inappropriate to then start a relationship with this person when your placement ends.

The GMC states that serious or repeated failure to abide by these guidelines will risk your registration. If in doubt consult a colleague or your defence union.
links:
GMC00
Maintaining a professional boundary between you and your patient

options: Prescribe orlistat on the NHS to minimise risk to patient from fake drugs
Agree to monitor his symptoms whilst on treatment
Prescribe orlistat as a private script to minimise risk to patient from fake drugs
Discuss the reasons he is so keen to lose weight
Refuse to prescribe orlistat
Refuse to monitor any symptoms related to orlistat to avoid legitimising his dangerous behaviour
Send him a letter of warning regarding his behaviour
questions:
You are a F2 doctor in General Practice. Your next patient is a 45-year-old man. He has always struggled with his weight and admits that he is currently using orlistat which he obtains from an internet pharmacy. He has read you can get some 'bowel problems' whilst taking it. After weighing him you calculate his BMI as 26.5 and hence he would not normally qualify for treatment on the NHS. He asks you if would prescribe him orlistat to avoid him having to get it from the internet.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
With the rise of 'internet pharmacies' patients are increasingly able to obtain drugs without seeing a doctor. This raises a number of dilemmas such as whether to continue treatment you would have not normally started.

The answer to this question is reasonably straightforward if we take a simple approach. Firstly he is only slightly overweight so it is therefore appropriate to explore why he is so keen to lose weight. Secondly, if he does not qualify for orlistat treatment then it should not be prescribed, be it on the NHS or privately. This does not however stop you from trying to reduce the risks of self-treatment by monitoring his symptoms.
